articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Completes Return From Wilderness to the White House
articles.snippet: An influx of alumni under Donald J. Trump provokes little backlash, as fears of undue influence mix with relief that the executive branch has some adult supervision.
articles.abstract: An influx of alumni under Donald J. Trump provokes little backlash, as fears of undue influence mix with relief that the executive branch has some adult supervision.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Accuses Fiat Chrysler of Secretly Violating Emissions Standards
articles.snippet: Federal regulators said the automaker used secret software that allowed more than 100,000 vehicles to emit illegal levels of harmful pollutants.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators said the automaker used secret software that allowed more than 100,000 vehicles to emit illegal levels of harmful pollutants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday accused Fiat Chrysler of installing secret software that allowed more than 100,000 of its diesel vehicles to emit pollutants above legal levels.

articles.headline: Comey Letter on Clinton Email Is Subject of Justice Dept. Inquiry
articles.snippet: The department’s inspector general will look into James B. Comey’s hotly debated decision to inform Congress about a new review of the Hillary Clinton email case.
articles.abstract: The department’s inspector general will look into James B. Comey’s hotly debated decision to inform Congress about a new review of the Hillary Clinton email case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s inspector general said Thursday that he would open a broad investigation into how the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, handled the case over Hillary Clinton’s emails, including his decision to discuss it at a news conference and to disclose 11 days before the election that he had new information that could lead him to reopen it.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Eric Lichtblau and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Justice Department Toughened Approach on Corporate Crime, but Will That Last?
articles.snippet: After “too big to jail” criticism from the financial crisis, the department has had success pursuing corporate employees. Now the two prosecutors who led the push are leaving.
articles.abstract: After “too big to jail” criticism from the financial crisis, the department has had success pursuing corporate employees. Now the two prosecutors who led the push are leaving.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the dust settled on the 2008 financial crisis, not a single top Wall Street executive went to prison.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Obama Ends Exemption for Cubans Who Arrive Without Visas
articles.snippet: The unexpected change to a policy unique to Cubans has long been sought by the Cuban government.
articles.abstract: The unexpected change to a policy unique to Cubans has long been sought by the Cuban government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that he was terminating the 22-year-old policy that has allowed Cubans who arrived on United States soil without visas to remain in the country and gain legal residency, an unexpected move long sought by the Cuban government.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Latest to Disagree With Donald Trump: His Cabinet Nominees
articles.snippet: In their first week before congressional panels, Mr. Trump’s cabinet nominees broke with him on almost every major policy that has put Mr. Trump outside Republican orthodoxy.
articles.abstract: In their first week before congressional panels, Mr. Trump’s cabinet nominees broke with him on almost every major policy that has put Mr. Trump outside Republican orthodoxy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America should not torture. Russia is a menace. A wall at the Mexican border would not be effective. A blanket ban against Muslims is wrong. Climate change is a threat.

articles.headline: Amazon to Add 100,000 Jobs as Bricks-and-Mortar Retail Crumbles
articles.snippet: The announcement by the online giant reflects what an economist sees as an inevitable process in which new industries rise and replace old ones.
articles.abstract: The announcement by the online giant reflects what an economist sees as an inevitable process in which new industries rise and replace old ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon’s new warehouse in Baltimore is a rare economic bright spot there, employing 3,000 people full-time in a city ravaged by poverty and a lack of opportunities for less educated workers.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: C.I.A. Nominee Says He Won’t Balk at Seeking Russian Intelligence
articles.snippet: Representative Mike Pompeo made clear he was ready to take on America’s old adversary, even as President-elect Donald J. Trump denigrates the nation’s spy agencies.
articles.abstract: Representative Mike Pompeo made clear he was ready to take on America’s old adversary, even as President-elect Donald J. Trump denigrates the nation’s spy agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first battle that Representative Mike Pompeo prepared to fight was against the Russians, when he commanded a tank platoon in Germany in the twilight of the Cold War. On Thursday, he made clear he was ready to take on America’s old adversary if confirmed as director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Chelsea Manning Describes Bleak Life in a Men’s Prison
articles.snippet: The former Army intelligence analyst who disclosed files to WikiLeaks hopes to be allowed to move ahead with her gender reassignment and her life.
articles.abstract: The former Army intelligence analyst who disclosed files to WikiLeaks hopes to be allowed to move ahead with her gender reassignment and her life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most mornings at 4:30, half an hour before the “first call” awakens inmates at the Fort Leavenworth military prison in Kansas, an alarm rings within an 80-square-foot cell. Inmate 89289, slightly built with short hair, rises to apply makeup and don female undergarments and a brown uniform before the still-slumbering men in the adjacent cells stir.

articles.headline: You Don’t Want What Wells Fargo Is Selling. What Should It Do Now?
articles.snippet: Scandals aside, most of Wells Fargo’s products have been mediocre at best — but the bank could mend fences by being more generous, fair and clear.
articles.abstract: Scandals aside, most of Wells Fargo’s products have been mediocre at best — but the bank could mend fences by being more generous, fair and clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Wells Fargo announced its quarterly earnings Friday morning, it was clear that many of its customers were not exactly pleased.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Affirms Fuel-Economy Goals, Frustrating Automakers
articles.snippet: Automakers are expected to ask the incoming Trump administration to review the decision by federal regulators to maintain standards for reducing harmful emissions.
articles.abstract: Automakers are expected to ask the incoming Trump administration to review the decision by federal regulators to maintain standards for reducing harmful emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal regulators on Friday affirmed long-term fuel-economy goals central to the Obama administration’s efforts to reduce harmful emissions from cars and trucks sold in the United States.
